The surge did work. I was there in Baghdad from November 07 to Feb 09, and I saw the difference in places like Sadr City first hand. In conjunction with the surge the biggest shift was in th ability of the Iraqi Army and Police to conduct operations on their own or with limited assistance. After the invasion in 2003 the Iraqi military ceased to exist. In 2004 the Iraqi Army began to be rebuilt, but they lacked everything from vehicles to tanks to supplies of uniforms. By the time I left our basic training mission went from 1200-1500 soldiers per cycle to 300-400 because the divisions are at strength and they were not building new manuever units. One of the biggest successes was conducting actual Warfighter exercises on a battalion scale. We taught the staffs, COIN, and battle tracking. The surge did work. I was there in Baghdad from November 07 to Feb 09, and I saw the difference in places like Sadr City first hand. In conjunction with the surge the biggest shift was in th ability of the Iraqi Army and Police to conduct operations on their own or with limited assistance. After the invasion in 2003 the Iraqi military ceased to exist. In 2004 the Iraqi Army began to be rebuilt, but they lacked everything from vehicles to tanks to supplies of uniforms. In Iraqi I was on a training team under MNSTC-I, the other 3 star command there besides MNC-I. I lived and worked at an Iraqi regional training center. Over the course of the year I was there we graduated nearly 10,000 Iraqi soldiers from basic training, and we were just one of a dozen training centers. We also fielded tens of thousands of M-16s and M-4s, thousands of HMMWVs, over 10,000 SINCGARS variant radios, and had an operating CIF for uniforms and field gear. We built ranges, obstacle courses, live fire shoot houses, and many other things. By the time I left our basic training mission went from 1200-1500 soldiers per cycle to 300-400 because the divisions are at strength and they were not building new manuever units. One of the biggest successes was conducting actual Warfighter exercises on a battalion scale. We taught the staffs, COIN, and battle tracking. The surge provided the breathing room and security to build confidence in the Iraqi's own security forces. Like us they have an AVF, and they are not short of recruits. That is the success in Iraq. I met and worked with hundreds of young IA officers and soldiers that know their business. They have the training, they are capable, and now they are out doing it.

In conjunction with the surge the biggest shift was in th ability of the Iraqi Army and Police to conduct operations on their own or with limited assistance. After the invasion in 2003 the Iraqi military ceased to exist. In 2004 the Iraqi Army began to be rebuilt, but they lacked everything from vehicles to tanks to supplies of uniforms.
